text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R package maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) series system parameters masked component failure data. package implements likelihood models systems : - Component lifetimes may masked (right-censored, left-censored, interval-censored) - Component cause failure masked via candidate sets (subsets components plausibly contain failed component) - Various masking conditions (C1, C2, C3) can satisfied relaxed

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package built likelihood.model framework, provides: - Generic likelihood contribution models via likelihood_contr_model - Methods MLE fitting, bootstrapping, confidence intervals - Integration algebraic.mle MLE objects methods like predict(), confint(), vcov()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Models characterized three conditions: - C1: Failed component candidate set probability 1 - C2: Uniform probability candidate sets conditioned component cause - C3: Masking probabilities independent system parameters

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Exponential series system distribution functions: - rexp_series(): Random generation (optional keep_latent parameter retain component lifetimes) - dexp_series(), pexp_series(), qexp_series(): PDF, CDF, quantile functions - hazard_exp_series(), surv.exp_series(): Hazard survival functions - mean.exp_series(): Mean function exponential series Key implementation detail: series system exponential components rates Œª‚ÇÅ,...,Œª‚Çò, system lifetime exponentially distributed rate Œª = Œ£Œª‚±º.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Implements likelihood model exponential series masked data satisfying C1, C2, C3: - exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3(): Constructor likelihood model object (returns S3 object class vector c("exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model")) - S3 methods: loglik(), score(), hess_loglik(), assumptions() dispatch model functions work data frames containing: - t (custom): System lifetime column - x1, x2, ..., xm (custom prefix): Boolean candidate set indicators Generic Dispatch Pattern: package uses S3 generic dispatch. Generics likelihood.model (loglik, score, hess_loglik, assumptions, fim) generics (fit) re-exported:
code: model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3()  # Get function generators via generic dispatch ll_fn <- loglik(model)   # Returns function(df, par, ...) s_fn <- score(model)     # Returns function(df, par, ...) H_fn <- hess_loglik(model)  # Returns function(df, par, ...)  # Evaluate directly ll_value <- ll_fn(df, par = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2))  # Or fit using the generic fit() function solver <- fit(model) mle_result <- solver(df, par = c(1, 1, 1)) cat("Estimates:", mle_result$theta.hat)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Functions generating working masked data: Lifetime Masking: - md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(): Applies right-censoring series system lifetimes - Reads component lifetimes columns t1, t2, ... (custom prefix) - Adds t (system lifetime = min component lifetimes censoring time tau) - Adds delta (right-censoring indicator: TRUE = exact, FALSE = right-censored) - Marks component lifetimes latent using md_mark_latent() Component Cause Masking: - md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(): Generates Bernoulli candidate set probabilities satisfying C1, C2, C3 - Reads component lifetimes t1, t2, ... columns - Creates probability columns q1, q2, ... q‚±º = 1 failed component, q‚±º = p otherwise - system right-censored (delta = FALSE), sets probabilities 0 - Returns data frame added q columns (marked latent) Reads probability columns q1, q2, ... Samples Boolean candidate set indicators x1, x2, ... x‚±º ~ Bernoulli(q‚±º) Returns data frame added x columns

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Generate/load component lifetime data (t1, t2, ...) Apply system lifetime masking ‚Üí add t, delta columns via md_series_lifetime_right_censoring() Generate candidate set probabilities ‚Üí add q1, q2, ... columns via md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3() Sample candidate sets ‚Üí add x1, x2, ... columns via md_cand_sampler() Fit likelihood model using x columns t column Example:
code: library(likelihood.model.series.md)  # Step 1: Generate component lifetimes df <- data.frame(   t1 = rexp(100, 0.5),   t2 = rexp(100, 0.3),   t3 = rexp(100, 0.2) )  # Step 2: Apply right-censoring df <- md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(df, tau = 10)  # Step 3: Generate candidate set probabilities df <- md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(df, p = 0.3)  # Step 4: Sample candidate sets df <- md_cand_sampler(df)  # Step 5: Fit likelihood model using generic dispatch model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3() solver <- fit(model) mle <- solver(df, par = c(1, 1, 1))  # Access results mle$theta.hat      # MLE estimates mle$sigma          # Standard errors mle$info           # Fisher information matrix print(mle)         # Pretty-printed summary with CIs

title: CLAUDE.md
text: t1, t2, ..., tm: Component lifetimes (often latent/unobserved) t: Series system lifetime (minimum component lifetimes censored time) delta: Right-censoring indicator (TRUE = exact, FALSE = right-censored) q1, q2, ..., qm: Component inclusion probabilities candidate sets (latent) x1, x2, ..., xm: Boolean candidate set indicators (observed) Matrix encoding/decoding: Use md.tools::md_decode_matrix() md.tools::md_encode_matrix() convert wide format (columns prefix1, prefix2, ...) matrix format.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package depends several related packages author (installed via GitHub remotes DESCRIPTION): - md.tools: Utilities encoding/decoding masked data matrices (md_decode_matrix, md_encode_matrix, md_mark_latent) - algebraic.mle: MLE objects rich method support (access estimates via $theta.hat, $sigma, $info) - algebraic.dist: Distribution algebra utilities - likelihood.model: General likelihood model framework providing generic functions (loglik, score, hess_loglik, assumptions, fim) fit.likelihood_model - generics: Provides fit generic (re-exported package) Re-exported Generics: package re-exports loglik, score, hess_loglik, assumptions, fim likelihood.model fit generics, users need load package.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: cum_haz(): Creates cumulative hazard function hazard function qcomp(): Quantile function component custom hazard/survival rcomp(): Random generation component custom hazard/survival

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Functions use snake_case (e.g., md_series_lifetime_right_censoring) Distribution functions follow R conventions: d* (density), p* (CDF), q* (quantile), r* (random) Model constructors return S3 objects class vectors like c("exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model") S3 methods registered properly using #' @method generic class #' @export roxygen2 tags Column prefixes: t (time), q (probability), x (candidate set boolean), delta (censoring indicator)

Suppose exponential series system mm components parameterized following R code: , study, Œ∏=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)‚Ä≤\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. component assigned index jj exponentially distributed lifetime failure rate Œ∏j\theta_j, e.g., Œ∏2=1.1\theta_2 = 1.1 failure rate component indexed 22. Let‚Äôs simulate generating lifetimes m=5m = 5 components series system: Next, use function md_series_lifetime_right_censoring decorate masked data right-censor-censoring time chosen probability Pr{Ti>œÑ}=0.75\Pr\{T_i > \tau\} = 0.75:
code: theta <- c(1,     # component 1 failure rate            1.1,   # 3            0.95,  # 5            1.15,  # 6            1.1)   # 7  m <- length(theta) set.seed(7231) # set seed for reproducibility n <- 7500 comp_times <- matrix(nrow=n,ncol=m) for (j in 1:m)     comp_times[,j] <- rexp(n,theta[j]) comp_times <- md_encode_matrix(comp_times,"t") print(comp_times,n=4) #> # A tibble: 7,500 √ó 5 #>      t1     t2    t3     t4    t5 #>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1  2.95 1.67   0.777 0.0476 0.380 #> 2  1.10 2.20   2.59  3.27   0.626 #> 3  1.20 0.0956 3.74  1.80   2.13  #> 4  1.44 0.0460 0.123 0.522  0.102 #> # ‚Ñπ 7,496 more rows q <- 0.25 tau <- rep(-(1/sum(theta))*log(q),n) data <- comp_times %>% md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau) print(data,n=4,drop_latent=TRUE) #> Latent variables:  t1 t2 t3 t4 t5  #> # A tibble: 7,500 √ó 2 #>        t delta #>    <dbl> <lgl> #> 1 0.0476 TRUE  #> 2 0.262  FALSE #> 3 0.0956 TRUE  #> 4 0.0460 TRUE  #> # ‚Ñπ 7,496 more rows

Newton-Raphson method needs observed information matrix, function Œª\lambda type ‚Ñùm‚Ü¶‚Ñùm√óm\mathbb{R}^m \mapsto \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}. (j,k)(j,k)-th element J(Œª)J(\lambda) given ‚àÇ2‚Ñì‚àÇŒªj‚àÇŒªk=‚àë=1n(‚àëj‚ààciŒªj)‚àí21{j,k‚ààci Œ¥i=0}.\begin{equation} \label{eq:info_expo} \frac{\partial^2 \ell}{\partial \lambda_j \partial \lambda_k} =    \sum_{=1}^{n} \biggl( \sum_{j \c_i} \lambda_j \biggr)^{-2}   1_{\{j,k \c_i \text{ } \delta_i = 0\}}. \end{equation}

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: reduced log-likelihood function (log kernel likelihood function) given ‚Ñì(Œ∏|data)=‚àí(‚àë=1nti)(‚àëj=1mŒ∏j)+‚àë=1n(1‚àíŒ¥i)log(‚àëj‚ààciŒ∏j). \ell(\theta|\text{data}) =     -\left(\sum_{=1}^{n} t_i\right)     \left(\sum_{j=1}^{m} \theta_j\right) +     \sum_{=1}^{n} (1-\delta_i)\log\left(\sum_{j \c_i} \theta_j\right). compute log-likelihood function using generic dispatch: returned function ll(df, par) evaluates log-likelihood parameter par given data df. example, true parameter value: Note implementation uses minimally sufficient statistics, improves computational efficiency. log-likelihood function contains maximum amount information parameter Œ∏\theta given sample masked data data satisfying conditions C1C_1, C2C_2, C3C_3. Suppose know Œ∏=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)‚Ä≤\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. log-likelihood, may estimate Œ∏\theta Œ∏ÃÇ\hat\theta solving Œ∏ÃÇ=argmaxŒ∏‚ààŒ©‚Ñì(Œ∏), \hat{\theta} = \operatorname{argmax}_{\theta \\Omega} \ell(\theta),  .e., finding point maximizes log-likelihood observed sample data. known maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). typically solve MLE solving ‚àá‚Ñì|Œ∏=Œ∏ÃÇ=0. \nabla \ell|_{\theta=\hat{\theta}} = 0. popular choice gradient ascent, iterative method based update rule Œ∏(n+1)=Œ∏n+Œ∑‚Ñì(Œ∏n), \theta^{(n+1)} = \theta^n + \eta \ell(\theta^n),  Œ∑\eta learning rate. can also obtain score (gradient) function via generic dispatch: score true parameter close zero (MLE, exactly zero): likelihood.model framework provides analytical score Hessian implementations available, falling back numerical differentiation otherwise. follows, use algebraic.mle help solve MLE equations display various properties solution. solve MLE equation, use generic fit() function, dispatches fit.likelihood_model object "likelihood_model" class. fit() function returns solver uses optim internally BFGS method default. result mle object algebraic.mle package rich accessor methods: can access specific components MLE: Recall true parameter Œ∏=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)‚Ä≤\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. Due sampling variability, different runs experiment result different outcomes, .e., Œ∏ÃÇ\hat{\theta} sampling distribution. see Œ∏ÃÇ‚â†Œ∏\hat{\theta} \neq \theta, reasonably close. may measure sampling variability using variance-covariance matrix, bias, mean squared error (MSE), confidence intervals.

ll <- loglik(model) ll(data, theta) #> [1] -1485 grad <- score(model) grad(data, theta) #> [1] -28.488  12.506  -9.824 -24.504 -12.322 # Get the solver from the model using generic dispatch solver <- fit(model)  # Solve for MLE with initial guess theta0 <- rep(1, m) estimate <- solver(data, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead") # Print summary with confidence intervals print(estimate) #> Maximum likelihood estimator of type mle_likelihood_model is normally distributed. #> The estimates of the parameters are given by: #> [1] 0.9545 1.1430 0.9440 1.1085 1.0881 #> The standard error is  0.04314 0.04496 0.04247 0.04481 0.04465 . #> The asymptotic 95% confidence interval of the parameters are given by: #>          2.5% 97.5% #> param1 0.8700 1.039 #> param2 1.0549 1.231 #> param3 0.8607 1.027 #> param4 1.0207 1.196 #> param5 1.0005 1.176 #> The MSE of the individual components in a multivariate estimator is: #>            [,1]       [,2]       [,3]       [,4]       [,5] #> [1,]  0.0018608 -0.0002202 -0.0002258 -0.0002585 -0.0002654 #> [2,] -0.0002202  0.0020211 -0.0002331 -0.0002648 -0.0002360 #> [3,] -0.0002258 -0.0002331  0.0018034 -0.0002185 -0.0002453 #> [4,] -0.0002585 -0.0002648 -0.0002185  0.0020078 -0.0002316 #> [5,] -0.0002654 -0.0002360 -0.0002453 -0.0002316  0.0019936 #> The log-likelihood is  -1483 . #> The AIC is  2976 . # Point estimate theta.hat <- estimate$theta.hat cat("MLE:", round(theta.hat, 4), "
